stages.title: The Amphora's Creation
stages.blurb: The Greek amphora, an iconic vessel, was crafted for both practical and ceremonial use. Its large size made it ideal for storing oil, wine, or grain.

content_blocks.title: Material and Shaping
content_blocks.text: Made from fine clay, the amphora was shaped on a potterâ€™s wheel, a technique that allowed for greater precision and speed in creating symmetrical forms.

content_blocks.title: Firing in the Kiln
content_blocks.text: The amphora was fired in a kiln at high temperatures, which made the clay durable. The firing process was essential to ensuring the amphora could hold liquids without leaking.

content_blocks.title: Handles and Base
content_blocks.text: The amphora's distinct handles and base allowed it to be easily carried and stored. These features reflect its use in both daily life and ceremonial settings.

stages.title: The Painted Designs
stages.blurb: The amphora was often decorated with scenes from mythology, daily life, and athletic competitions. These designs reflected the cultural values of ancient Greece.

content_blocks.title: Red-Figure Painting
content_blocks.text: In red-figure painting, the background was painted black, leaving the figures in the natural red color of the clay. This technique allowed for more detailed and expressive figures.

content_blocks.title: Depictions of Myths
content_blocks.text: Many amphorae depict scenes from Greek mythology, featuring gods, heroes, and mythical creatures. These stories were central to Greek culture and often conveyed moral lessons.

content_blocks.title: Athletic Competitions
content_blocks.text: Some amphorae were awarded as prizes in athletic competitions, particularly during the Panathenaic Games. These vases were often decorated with scenes of athletes in action.

stages.title: The Amphora's Function
stages.blurb: The Greek amphora served as both a functional object and a work of art. Its uses ranged from the storage of goods to its role in religious and social ceremonies.

content_blocks.title: Storing Oil and Wine
content_blocks.text: Amphorae were commonly used to store oil and wine. Their narrow necks and wide bodies helped preserve these valuable goods for longer periods.

content_blocks.title: Ceremonial Uses
content_blocks.text: Amphorae were often used in religious ceremonies, where they carried offerings of wine or oil to the gods. Their artistic designs made them suitable for sacred contexts.

content_blocks.title: Enduring Legacy
content_blocks.text: The Greek amphora remains an enduring symbol of ancient craftsmanship. Its shape and decorative elements influenced pottery across the Mediterranean.
